div.l: Than were there yong scolers two
That duelden in this halle of whiche I sey
Testyf they were and lusty for to pley
And only for theire myrth and reualrye
Vpon the warden besily they cry
To yeue them leue but a lytel stounde
To go to the mylle and se theire corne y grounde
And hardely they durst ley theire necke
The myller sholde nat stele half a pecke
Of corn by sleyght ne by force them reue
And at the last the wardyn yaue them leue
Iohn hyght that one and aleyn hight that other
Of a toun were they born that hight strodre
Fer in the north I can nat telle where
This aleyn makith redy alle his gere
And on an horse the sackes he caste anone
Forth goth aleyn the clerke and eke Iohn
With gode swerde and bocler by his syde
Iohn knewe the wey him nedith no gyde
And at the mylle the sackes adoun he leyeth
Aleyn spake first al hayle symond in feyth
How farys the fayre doughter and thy wyf
Aleyn welcom quod Symkyn by my lyf
And Iohn also hou now what do ye here
Symond quod Iohn nede hath no pere
Him must nedes serue him selue that hath no swayn
Or elles he is a fole as clerkes seyn
Our manciple I hope he wille be dede
So workith ay there wangys in his hede
And therfore I am come and this aleyn
To grynde oure corn and cary it home ageyn
I pray you spede vs hens in that ye may
It shalbe do quod Symkyn by my fay
